awd_titl_txt: CNH-L: Pastoral Territory as a Dynamic Coupled System
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary research project will examine the environmental conditions that lead to human territorial behavior in the pastoral ecosystems as well as how territoriality shapes the environment.  The project will provide new insights into whether the dynamics of woodland-grassland-woodland cycling are coupled with pulses in human social behavior.  Through their examination of archaeological and paleoecological data, the investigators will provide new insights regarding the degree to which such long-term cycling-and-coupling provides alternative perspectives about human-environmental interaction.  The project will challenge paradigm characterizations of a linear history of progressive human degradation of pasture lands by refining and testing a new theoretical model that explains pastoral territoriality as a dynamic coupled system.  By focusing attention on the nonlinear dynamics of change and continuity in coupled human and natural systems, the project will provide a new conceptual approach for examining change and continuity in prehistoric societies.  Assessment of dynamic, interlocked cycles of human territorial behavior and rangeland ecology have broader implications for development and sustainability of human environments as coupled systems.  The project will provide education and training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in the transdisciplinary study of complex social-ecological systems, and it will further collaborations between researchers in the U.S. and the Middle East.

Using archaeological, ecological, geochemical, paleoclimate, and botanical methods in fieldwork, the investigators will recover and study proxy data as the material residues from ancient environments and human societies that have been engaged in pastoralism.  The research team, which includes researchers from the United States, United Kingdom, Germany, and Oman, will use agent-based models to examine the interactions of human and natural systems and to test the model of coupled dynamics with data from the field.  They will employ an integrative and reiterative research approach, tuning models with data and generating expected patterns from models.  They will address a general hypothesis that dynamic feedbacks among pastoralist demography, mobility, territoriality, and processes of succession in past vegetation regimes account for the observed pattern of chronological pulses in building stone territorial markers.  Although this project will be based in the narrow plateau pasturelands of southern Oman because that region exhibits 8,000 years of exclusively pastoral economy and a rich archaeological and paleoecological record, project findings will have significant implications for examining interactions between people and pastoral environments over time in the U.S. and elsewhere.  This project is supported by the NSF Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems (CNH) Program.

PASTORAL TERRITORIALITY AS A DYNAMIC COUPLED SYSTEM

The research examines under what environmental conditions territoriality emerges in pastoral ecosystems and how territoriality in turn shapes the environment.  Recognizing the roles of human movements, population growth, and the state of rangelands in long-term dynamics of pastoralism, we studied how four variables--mobility, demography, territoriality, and vegetation dynamics can cause cycling or push the pastoral ecosystem from one state to another, as in an adaptive cycle switching between open and closed (territorial) access to resources. We hypothesized that coupling in the human systems (mobility, social rules of territorial and open property) and natural systems (vegetation, demography) explains long-term patterns. The research engaged methods from paleoecology, archaeology, and interdisciplinary computational modeling study to study human landscapes and historical changes in vegetation over 6000 years in Dhofar (Southern Oman).

 

Figure 1. Map of Dhofar?s four major geographical zones: dry coastland, forested escarpment, grassy plateau, and stony desert.

 

Paleoecology: For the first time from Oman, the ASOM Project team (Ancient Socioecological systems of OMan) located and sampled fossilized hyrax latrine deposits. Hyraxes resemble large rodents. Their dens contain cumulative deposits of dried urine that preserved ancient plant fragments and pollen. By analyzing pollen and plants, we generated a vegetation and climate history of Oman?s stony deserts that complements the results from similar hyrax latrines found in Yemen. Our studies indicate that today?s woodland taxa penetrated further into the desert about 4000 years ago, to be replaced by herbaceous taxa 2900 years ago. This outcome is consistent with climatic shifts detected in other Arabian records. From 1000 years ago, domestic pastoral animals?likely camels?left distinctive traces as spores from decomposing camel dung. Our localized results build a composite record of landscape, with its regional responses to climate and spatially variable impacts by humans. Not only did we provide desert records where other traditional records are missing, but we also offer a context for reconstructing ancient human activity and socio-ecosystem dynamics. 

 

Archaeology: Our archaeological timeline of monument and settlement episodes is a foundational contribution to research on Southern Arabia?s past and human-natural systems. We documented 20 monuments in two tributaries, adding these monuments to hundreds previously known and 37 previously excavated. On the assumption that stone monuments imply ancient social groups? territorial interests, our team paid particular attention to when and where people collaborated to build monuments or settled down. We identified long intervals, during which mobile pastoral populations in the desert constructed monuments of different types, indicative of different cultural practices like raising a tomb or placing a collective memorial. Desert pastoralists remained mobile and built no settlements. In the escarpment zone, we found ancient settlements. Our 26 new radiocarbon determinations (dates) on these settlements clarify a timeline of ancient human activities. Best represented in chart format (Figure 2), monuments called ?platforms? appear in the desert 7500-6000 years ago,  circular tombs 5300-4000 years ago, ?trilith? monuments 2400-1600 years ago, and after another gap, boat-shaped graves 1200-800 years ago. In the plateau and escarpment, a singular phase of settlement occurred between 2400-1600 years ago, during an exceptionally arid period. Archaeological deposits indicate persistent mobility by people pasturing cattle, sheep, and goats, with significant hunting. Nothing suggests use of domesticated crops?there are no archaeological remains from crops, nor are there processing tools like sickles, grinding stones, cooking pots, griddle stones or other plant-food technologies. We deposited registered artifacts with the Ministry of Heritage and Culture, Sultanate of Oman.

 

Figure 2. A Timeline of Archaeological monuments (yellow) and settlements.

 

Computational Modeling: The team built an agent-based model of Dhofar?s pastoral ecosystem. The model represents the climate, ecology, and the social system of pastoralists in Dhofar. The model allows the team to run simulations for hundreds and thousands of years and examine the dynamic feedbacks between climate change, pastoral populations, and rangeland ecology, and in particular shifts in mobility patterns and territorial behavior. The agent-based model will be published in the CoMSES Computational Model Library, and this will allow other researchers to use our model to examine the dynamics of pastoral systems in Dhofar and elsewhere.

 

In broader impacts, we trained four undergraduate students, ten graduate students, and two postdoctoral researchers in interdisciplinary research of coupled human and natural systems. In addition, we trained 60+ middle and high school students in the use of agent-based models in two summer camps at the PAST Foundation (Columbus, Ohio) and the Translational Data Analytics Institute (TDAI) at the Ohio State University. Team members published a book (Persistent Pastoralism), three book chapters, contributed to an award-winning archaeological fieldwork report (Landscape History of Hadramawt), eight peer-reviewed journal articles, gave twelve professional presentations, and provided the basis for three PhD dissertations and four undergraduate research theses. Finally, the team strengthened scientific collaborations with the Ministry of Heritage and Tourism and developed scientific collaborations with the Oman Botanical Garden.
